Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

This past summer, I began going through the Arcadian newsletters to see whi=
ch programs won the $100 prize in each issue.  I was pretty surprised to fi=
nd out how spotty the timing of the contest was each issue.  I began making=
 a list of all the winners, fully expecting there to be a winner every issu=
e, but that isn't the case at all.


I wanted to flesh-out this listing mor=
e, but I probably won't get to it, so here it is for everyone to check out.=
  Try some of the games on this list in AstroBASIC.  Most, or maybe even al=
l of them, are available on BallyAlley.com.


Maybe I'll make a segment on =
the Astrocast about the Arcadian contest; that would be neat.  Let me know =
if anyone is interested in such a segment.


Adam


The listing of the priz=
ewinners follows:


Arcadian Program Prizewinners ($100 contest winners)

A=
ugust 10, 2016

Compiled by Adam Trionfo



By reading through the issues o=
f the Arcadian, I've noted that there were 17 prizewinners.  I was under th=
e impression that there were many more than this, but there are many months=
 when no contest took place.



March 1981     - Idea of contest announced,=
 but no winner for this issue



April 1981     - Programming contest idea =
still in progress, no winner for this issue



May 1981       - $100 Arcadi=
an Programming Contest formally announced.  Programs must be originals, not=
 translations.  No winner this issue.



June 1981      - No winner this is=
sue.



July 1981      - Old Bent Nose, by Bob Wiseman - ARCADIAN 3, no. 9 =
(Jul. 09, 1981): 96.



August 1981    - Bally Black Box, by Steve Walters =
- ARCADIAN 3, no. 10 (Aug. 12, 1981): 103-105.



September 1981 - Telling =
Time, by Bob Hensel - ARCADIAN 3, no. 11 (Sep. 11, 1981): 114-115.



Octob=
er 1981   - Rebound, by Dave Martin - ARCADIAN 3, no. 12 (Oct. 05, 1981): 1=
24. Reprint, with additions: ARCADIAN 6, no. 6 (Apr. 20, 1984): 54.



Nove=
mber 1981  - 4D2, by Rusty Blommaert and Dale Smith - ARCADIAN 4, no. 1 (No=
v. 10, 1981): 5,8.  Reprint, for AstroBASIC: ARCADIAN 6, no. 11 (Oct. 31, 1=
984): 126.



December 7, 1982 - No winner this issue because there were no=
 entries.



December 24 1982 - No winner this issue due to lack of time.

=


January 1982   - The Cube, by Bob Weber - ARCADIAN 4, no. 4 (Jan. 22, 198=
2): 36-37.



March 1982     - Budget Worksheet, by Robert Lauffer - ARCADI=
AN 4, no. 5 (Mar. 05, 1982): 48-50.



April 1982     - No winner this issu=
e



May 1982       - Stranded at Rigel, Sean Walsh - ARCADIAN 4, no. 7 (Ma=
y 07, 1982): 72-73.  Note: Bally BASIC only.



June 1982      - No winner =
this issue



July 1982      - Astro Zap 2000, by George Moses - ARCADIAN 4=
, no. 9 (Jul. 06, 1982): 88.



August 1982    - No winner this issue



Se=
ptember 1982 - No winner this issue



October 1982   - Word Hunt, by Antho=
ny Ross - ARCADIAN 4, no. 12 (Oct. 07, 1982): 115, 117.



November 1982  -=
 No winner this issue



December 1982  - No winner this issue



January 1=
983   - No winner this issue



February 1983  - No winner this issue



Ma=
rch 1983     - No winner this issue



April 1983     - "We have not had a =
contest this year yet due to a couple of technical difficulties."



May 19=
83       - Ghost Fleet, by Ken Lill - ARCADIAN 5, no. 7 (May 6, 1983): 107,=
111.



June 1983      - No Winner because there were no eligible programs.=
  Only reprints of the programs on the Bally Arcade tape.



July 1983     =
 - Frog Leap, by Dave Ibach - ARCADIAN 5, no. 9 (Jul. 22, 1983): 138,146.

=


August 1983    - Locksmith, by Don Crider - ARCADIAN 5, no. 10 (Aug. 16, =
1983): 157.



September 1983 - No winner this issue.  Possibly this is bec=
ause SHUTBOX, by Joseph Spiegal, is based on a dice game that Joseph used t=
o have when he was "younger."



October 1983   - No winner this issue.  Th=
ere are actually no programs in this issue!



November 1983  - No winner t=
his issue.  Three programs published, but they are all re-worked programs o=
f earlier programs, not original programs.



December 1983  - Frogway, by =
Mike Skala - ARCADIAN 6, no. 2 (Dec. 22, 1983): 12,16.



January 1984   - =
No winner this issue.  GOLDDIGGER is the only published program-- and it's =
for Extended BASIC, so perhaps it didn't qualify for the contest.



Februa=
ry 1984  - Dot-to-Dot, by Joe Peoples - ARCADIAN 6, no. 4 (Feb. 23, 1984): =
38.



March 1984     - No winner this issue.  Only one program published t=
his month: GRAVITY by Fred Rodney.



April 1984     - Shoot the Duck!, by =
James Wilchen - ARCADIAN 6, no. 6 (Apr. 20, 1984): 58.



May 1984       - =
No winner this issue.  Most programs are reprints or updates.



June 1984 =
      - Alien 2000, by Henry Sopko - ARCADIAN 6, no. 9 (Jul. 27, 1984): 74-=
75.



July 1984       - No winner this issue.  Four programs published thi=
s issue: two program updates (CONNECT FOUR and STATEGIC AIR COMMAND), a pro=
gram based on another game (GASWELL BONANZA) and, I think, an original prog=
ram called "ACME DRIVING TEST."



August 1984     - No winner this issue. =
 3 ARCADIAN reprints (ASTRO ZAP 2000, BASEBALL, TOWER OF HANOI), a reprint =
from Niagara BUGS Bulletin (CATERPILLAR), a program previously available fr=
om The Tiny Arcade on tape (QUADRON), and one game inspired by DONKEY KONG =
(SPACE APE).



October 1984     - No winner this issue.  This was going to=
 be the ARCADIAN's last issue, but it came back, as a quarterly, for one mo=
re year (volume 7).  ARCADIAN reprints (BLACK BOX), 7 original programs (KO=
NCENTRATION, CLOCK, THE GAME OF WAR, MAZE AVENGER, CRAZIE DICE, ROTATE, VID=
EO:VIDEO, unnamed and uncredited program on page 114-115), 3 reprints from =
Niagara BUGS Bulletin (4D2, LIZZARD LUNCH and REPACK), a program previously=
 available from WaveMakers on tape (BACKGAMMON), a program PROBABLY previou=
sly released on tape by Astrogames (METROPOLITAN ATTACK!), an update (CONNE=
CT FOUR ENLARGED, BATTLESHIP), a possible conversion (HOCKEY), a program pr=
eviously released on tape by Collins Computer Company (BALLY CHESS BOARD), =
a program previously released on tape by W&W Software (OTHELLO).



June 19=
85     - No winner this issue.



December 1985 - No winner this issue.



=
March 1985    - No winner this issue.



August 1985   - No winner this iss=
ue. (This is the last issue of the Arcadian)

n:yes"> 
</span>This was going to be the ARCADIAN's last issue, but it=

-spacerun:yes"> 
</span>ARCADIAN reprints (BLACK BOX), 7 original prog=
rams (KONCENTRATION, CLOCK, THE GAME OF WAR, MAZE AVENGER, CRAZIE DICE, ROT=
ATE, VIDEO:VIDEO, unnamed and uncredited program on page 114-115), 3 reprin=

reviously available from WaveMakers on tape (BACKGAMMON), a program PROBABL=

te (CONNECT FOUR ENLARGED, BATTLESHIP), a possible conversion (HOCKEY), a p=
rogram previously
 released on tape by Collins Computer Company (BALLY CHES=
S BOARD), a program previously released on tape by W&W Software (OTHELL=
O).</span></p>
